New Grant Awarded
For Chemical Work
The Johns Hopkins University
has been granted $29,000 by the
National Science Foundation for
continuation of research entitled
"Catalytic Hydrogenation Over
Metals" under the direction of
Dr. Paul H. Emmett, W.R. Grace
Professor of Chemistry at the
University.
The grant extends the fouryear project for two additional
years. Senior investigator in the
research is Dr. Gojko Kremenic,
a Research Associate from the
University of Madrid working at
Hopkins under a National Science Foundation Fellowship.
Dr. Emmett is internationally
known for his research in the
field of catalysis which led to a
better understanding of natural
forces that help produce changes
in matter. A native of Portland,
Oregon, Professor Emmett received the B.S. degree in 1922
from Oregon State College and
the Ph.D. in 192 from the California Institute of Technology.
After teaching for a year at
Oregon State College, he joined
the United States Department of
Agriculture, where he rose from
assistant to senior chemist.
From 1937 to 1944 he was professor of chemical engineering at
Johns Hopkins. After a year on
the Manhattan Project, he became a senior fellow on the
Multiple Petroleum Fellowship of
the Mellon Institute in Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, where he
remained for the next ten years.
He rejoined the Johns Hopkins

faculty in 1955 as W. R. Grace
Professor of Chemistry.
A member of the National
Academy of Sciences, he has won
the Pittsburgh Award of the
American Chemical Society's
Pittsburgh section and the Kendall Company Award in Colloid
Chemistry administered by the
American Chemical Society.

What Me Worry?
The hypocrisy of the administration and the inconsiderate planning of someone in the plant manager's
office were remarkably visible during the facelifting of
the Gilman main reading room during final exam week.
Every year, it seems, the administration decides to
clean up the dirt in and around the main reading room.
And, ironically, this always occurs just prior to Commemoration Day when that area of Gilman Hall is on
display to the Baltimore community and to guests of
the University at its anniversary celebration.
This year, however, the facelifting was more complete than it had been in several years. Painters did
patchwork in the main reading room during the very
week when silence was most needed in the central study
area on campus. At that time talking and smoking
painters added to the general commotion that usually
occurs around Miss Hubbard's desk and telephone which
resulted in a central room that was literally a zoo on
display to any students who wanted to take time from
studying. In fact students really had no choice about
ghouling there.
An ironic overtone to the cleanup was the stunningly incomplete job that was done to the crystal
chandeliers which hang in the Gilman Memorial Room.
The tear drop cut glass which dangle from the chandeliers were removed and polished while painters did a
fast refinishing of the ceiling and walls in the lobby of
the main reading room. When the painting was finished
the polished tear drops were replaced on the chandeliers
which still hold the dust which has fallen on them since
last year's Commemoration Day. Hopefully the bulk of
the chandeliers will remain dust laden until after Commemoration Day as a fit token of the attitude the
University takes to its facilities and their local users.
Two suggestions immediately present themselves
for the administrative overseers of the pre-Commemoration Day get-neat campaign. They should either leave
the reception rooms as they are during the remainder
of the year or give the cleaning crew a pep talk about
organization pride so that they keep things presentable
all year long. After all, it would be nice if the regular
users of the library were also privileged by a clean
environment too.
One more comment is provoked by the attitude
taken by the University toward Commemoration Day and
the Gilman facilities. Each year the six bulletin boards
in the hallway in front of the reading room are gifted
with new displays, again just prior to Commemoration
Day. During the remainder of the year they are neglected, left open to occasional bulletin-board lifters and
outdated. Last year's display had a check-list of University projects neatly decorated with red check marks
which indicated those projects already completed. This
display is precisely twelve months behind. But it is
colorful and gay. Maybe it can be salvaged along with
the dusty chandeliers so that the visiting group on
February 22 can gain a true insight into the way the
Hop ticks.

History Repeats
Joe Perrotto seems to have found the answer at
last. The way to make Hopkins bearable is to get out
of it. Joe, apparently elated with this hold and original
solution to the problem of survival in our mudhole,
has accepted a full-time job teaching in the Baltimore
school system. In spite of our best intentions, we must
question the good faith of such an action on the part
of the most important undergraduate on campus. We
cannot see why anyone as sincere, as uncalculating, as
genuinely well meaning as Perrotto should leave a
campus where he holds so much responsibility for undergraduate affairs. Nor can we see Perrotto's well known
ego allowing him to relinquish any of his hard earned
power.
So it looks as if there is now a part time leader,
if any, at all of the undergraduate body. Perhaps some
ambitious class president will form a committee to "get
things done around here" while Joe is busy elsewhere.
To keep things going in the style to which we have
become accustomed he might as well call it H4U.

Kudos
From all reports the Debate Council's annual invitation tournament was an unqualified success. The event
attracted thirty competing teams representing some of
the major colleges and universities in the East and went
off without a hitch. On a campus where most organizations seem bogged hopelessly in self congratulation and
procedural niggles, such positive and effective activity
is refreshingly welcome.
Kudos to the Debate Council; perhaps this will
Inspire the Student Council to form a much needed
Committee to Observe Well Run Campus Organizations.

Tennessee Williams' newest
play to open on Broadway, The
Milk Train Doesn't Stop Here
Any More, brings out another
facet of the new Williams, the
author who expresses his ideas
in words, rather than in the portrayal of violence and perversion.
The plot concerns Mrs. Flora
Goforth, a fantastically wealthy
lady in her early sixties, who is
in the process of writing her
memoirs, for, she says, an early
deadline. Actually, she is dying
of cancer, and desperatley fears
what is to come. As she wanders about her three luxurious
villas on the coast of Italy, dictating her memoirs, we learn
that she attained her wealth by
surviving six husbands. Of the
first five, each one was wealthier
and uglier than the next (one
she constantly refers to as "the
Big Ape"). But this did not deter
her: money and material wealth
were what she desired, and so
she willingly gave of her beautiful body in return for these
sources of luxury.

Ii

Goforth's sensual appetite is aroused again, at the
arrival of another young penniless, but handsome poet named
Chris Flanders. Enticed by the
poet's good looks, she decides on
one last fling. But before she
talks with him, Flora learns
from a friend that Chris is nicknamed the "Angel of Death," by
virtue of his previously having
stayed with seven elderly women, each of whom died while he
was there. Another thing that
amazes Flora is how this man,
with no means of transportation
could obtain entrance to her
villa, since the only route is by

the sea, or through a rugged
path through the mountains by
land. But Chris is here, and the
next morning Flora offers him
the luxury and monetary security of her care, in return for his
services as her lover. Most Williams heroes, like Chance Wayne
the gigolo in Sweet Bird of
Youth would have accepted this
offer gladly, and moralized over
it later, but Chris turns it down.
Rather he prefers to stay on and
give the dying women 'sympathy
and companionship," and "touch
the heart." The angered and rejected Flora tells him to see
things her way, or get out. And
when Chris chooses the latter,
in telling her he will visit another lady dying in Sicily, Mrs.
Goforth, knowing he is penniless, asks him sardonically,
"How do you expect to get
there? Can you walk on water?"
The allusion to Christ is
obvious, and therein, I feel, lies
the meaning of the play. What
Williams is saying is that only
a God can resist the temptations
of the flesh. It is part of what

can be called Williams' realistic
point of view, and describes an
almost universal human condition. As we grow up, we are
taught to believe in goodness
and idealistic values, but as we
become part of society, our
human needs and desire undermine these values. In the Williams world, one can moralize
forever, but very few can strictly
avoid natural temptations which
are branded immoral. Through
Flora's body, Chris may attain
all the material wealth that most
people in the world desire. Only
because he symbolizes a God is
he impervious to her sumptuous
offerings, thus enabling him to
avoid the fall into immorality

What Me Worry?
The hypocrisy of the administration and the inconsiderate planning of someone in the plant manager's
office were remarkably visible during the facelifting of
the Gilman main reading room during final exam week.
Every year, it seems, the administration decides to
clean up the dirt in and around the main reading room.
And, ironically, this always occurs just prior to Commemoration Day when that area of Gilman Hall is on
display to the Baltimore community and to guests of
the University at its anniversary celebration.
This year, however, the facelifting was more complete than it had been in several years. Painters did
patchwork in the main reading room during the very
week when silence was most needed in the central study
area on campus. At that time talking and smoking
painters added to the general commotion that usually
occurs around Miss Hubbard's desk and telephone which
resulted in a central room that was literally a zoo on
display to any students who wanted to take time from
studying. In fact students really had no choice about
ghouling there.
An ironic overtone to the cleanup was the stunningly incomplete job that was done to the crystal
chandeliers which hang in the Gilman Memorial Room.
The tear drop cut glass which dangle from the chandeliers were removed and polished while painters did a
fast refinishing of the ceiling and walls in the lobby of
the main reading room. When the painting was finished
the polished tear drops were replaced on the chandeliers
which still hold the dust which has fallen on them since
last year's Commemoration Day. Hopefully the bulk of
the chandeliers will remain dust laden until after Commemoration Day as a fit token of the attitude the
University takes to its facilities and their local users.
Two suggestions immediately present themselves
for the administrative overseers of the pre-Commemoration Day get-neat campaign. They should either leave
the reception rooms as they are during the remainder
of the year or give the cleaning crew a pep talk about
organization pride so that they keep things presentable
all year long. After all, it would be nice if the regular
users of the library were also privileged by a clean
environment too.
One more comment is provoked by the attitude
taken by the University toward Commemoration Day and
the Gilman facilities. Each year the six bulletin boards
in the hallway in front of the reading room are gifted
with new displays, again just prior to Commemoration
Day. During the remainder of the year they are neglected, left open to occasional bulletin-board lifters and
outdated. Last year's display had a check-list of University projects neatly decorated with red check marks
which indicated those projects already completed. This
display is precisely twelve months behind. But it is
colorful and gay. Maybe it can be salvaged along with
the dusty chandeliers so that the visiting group on
February 22 can gain a true insight into the way the
Hop ticks.

of it. Joe, apparently elated with this hold and original
solution to the problem of survival in our mudhole,
has accepted a full-time job teaching in the Baltimore
school system. In spite of our best intentions, we must

Tennessee Williams' newest
play to open on Broadway, The

Any More, brings out another
facet of the new Williams, the
author who expresses his ideas
in words, rather than in the portrayal of violence and perversion.
The plot concerns Mrs. Flora
Goforth, a fantastically wealthy
lady in her early sixties, who is
in the process of writing her
memoirs, for, she says, an early
deadline. Actually, she is dying
of cancer, and desperatley fears
what is to come. As she wanders about her three luxurious
villas on the coast of Italy, dictating her memoirs, we learn
that she attained her wealth by
surviving six husbands. Of the
first five, each one was wealthier
and uglier than the next (one
she constantly refers to as "the
Big Ape"). But this did not deter
her: money and material wealth
were what she desired, and so
she willingly gave of her beautiful body in return for these
sources of luxury.

Ii

Goforth's sensual appetite is aroused again, at the
arrival of another young penniless, but handsome poet named
Chris Flanders. Enticed by the
poet's good looks, she decides on
one last fling. But before she
talks with him, Flora learns
from a friend that Chris is nicknamed the "Angel of Death," by
virtue of his previously having
stayed with seven elderly women, each of whom died while he
was there. Another thing that
amazes Flora is how this man,
with no means of transportation
could obtain entrance to her
villa, since the only route is by

path through the mountains by
land. But Chris is here, and the
next morning Flora offers him
the luxury and monetary security of her care, in return for his
services as her lover. Most Williams heroes, like Chance Wayne
the gigolo in Sweet Bird of
Youth would have accepted this
offer gladly, and moralized over
it later, but Chris turns it down.

give the dying women 'sympathy
and companionship," and "touch
the heart." The angered and rejected Flora tells him to see

when Chris chooses the latter,

John T. Rettaliata, President

organization.
Dr. Rettaliata received his B.E.
from Johns Hopkins in 1932 and
his D. Eng. in 1936. He has
served as president of the Illinois
Institute of Technology since
1952 and is a director of several
chemical, electrical and research
corporations.
The ODK initiation will be
held in the afternoon of Feb. 21
and will be followed by a cocktail
party in the faculty club. Dr.
Rettaliata will be on campus to
celebrate the 50th anniversary of
the school of engineering which
